text: Hey emacians, I was using the julia repl to evaluate code in emacs, which works just fine. But the problem I am finding is that the repl does no store history. So if I run one command, then another command, then a third command, usually I can use the up arrow and go back through previous commands. However, I find that in the julia repl--at least in emacs, I can only go back 1 command. I think this might be a julia repl setting, since in other emacs shells my history goes back farther. Can anyone confirm this, or tell me what setting to change to increase the history buffer?

text:
I routinely use ctrl-p, ctrl-n to navigate history in julia-repl inside emacs.    I also sometimes use ctrl-r to search back for the line I want.

That being said, sometimes as you note navigating said history gets stuck - in that case, it helps to hit ctrl-c to stop the navigation and try again.

text: <@UAS2BRCBU> Yeah, I get what you mean. the nice thing about running in emacs compared to vscode, is that the julia evaluation of the buffer just seems so much faster. So I usually write the code in the buffer and then use `SPC m s b` in spacemacs to run it. That is why the history things was such a pain. Because after typing `SPC m s b`, the repl will have the `include(...jl)` file in it. But then I could not hit the up arrow to get beyond that include statement. So hopefully your suggestion will help get past that.
